>>18893526
I made a really nice one yesterday with spinach, olives, mushrooms, roasted garlic and parmesan. not my favourite pastsa in all but definitely my best "throw together what's left in the fridge" type pasta.

>slice baby button mushrooms, season
>fry in olive oil until they dry out and mailliard occurs
>slice black olives and add to pan with 3-4 cloves of roasted garlic and a tsp of butter, sweat 2-3 minutes
>meanwhile blanch some spinach in a colander
>finely chop wilted spinach and add to sauce
>add the pasta (fussili worked really well) when it's 2-3 minutes undercooked and a generous splash of pasta water
>cook for the remaining 2-3 minutes while stirring constantly
>add remove from heat, add cheese and some chopped parsley, and an extra drizzle of evoo, season to taste with salt and pepper

It was really, really nice, I might add some lemon next time but I'm not sure if that will make it better or worse.

I worked prep for a bit at a steakhouse and from my limited experience there's simply never enough hands to do the work. I eventually moved to line and every other prep cook besides the one middle aged dude who'd been doing prep his whole life would quit within a month because management would demand they stay extra hours to finish the prep list, but wouldn't try that shit with the middle aged dude since he was simply too valuable and always hopped out at 3 to pick up his kid.
By the time I left they had a new line cook's mom coming in during the afternoon to do the worst of the prep work like portioning linguini into bags for over an hour per day
Prep work at its best where you're making multiple fun recipes at a time is a great way to pass the time, the worst of it is just mind numbingly boring to where I'd take an understaffed 20 top walk in over it any time

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Been working at a place off and on for the last 4 years(covid and having a serious medical issue made it so it was more like 2 ACTUAL years of regular shifts).
Notice my raises were all but erased because of a minimum wage going up(Started off with the manager saying all line cooks start at $2 over minimum wage, and get raises every 9-12 months based on performance. Because of covid i never got the last 2 evaluations). Since then minimum wage has gone up by $1.85 cents.
New hires are actually paid more than me, even though i literally had to show one how to use a fucking thermometer last time i worked with him.
Tip-outs was also really exaggerated, with the manager saying it averages around $2/hr for BoH. At best, i did maybe $2.20/hr, but prob 80% of the time its around $1/hr.

Pretty fucking demoralized desu. I'm thinking of just handing in my notice tomorrow. I'm also given shitty shifts(like both opening shifts on the weekend. Something that i guess only a few other guys are trained to do.) that are impossible to offload and would cripple the business if i did a no-show.
I'll admit i'm probably one of the weaker cooks there if you only look at the people who are actually fully trained, but i'v never missed a day or came in late, never take breaks(so many other guys just fuck-off for smoke breaks or disappear in the bathroom for 20 minutes. I made it a point to not use the bathroom unless i literally need to) and have stayed past the end of my shift if asked.
I know its a shitty industry to work in, and i have said so myself plenty of times, but when i actually took a moment to reflect on it when i got my tax papers for it, it really hit me just how exploited i feel from working there.

posts.com:
>>18894083
At my place, we'd make i think 18L every 3 or 4 days, and keep it in a big cambro in the cooler. At the start of the day we'd heat up enough to fill a 1/3rd tray and keep it in a steamwell, and add to it if needed.

I also worked at a place that would portion it out in 10oz bags, and re-heat(in the microwave) to order. Steam well works better since its uniformly warm and for some stuff you need to put it in a pipping bag anyway, so having it portioned in a plastic bag is just wasteful and extra hassle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18879557
Never worked as a line cook, but I did briefly work at a factory that made frozen tv dinners and hot meals for Meals on Wheels, and cafeterias too. The guy that hooked me up with the job told me it was hard work, but the part he left out was just the INSANE amount of mental math I'd have to be constantly doing in order to make sure that the portions were equal....they were very adamant about perfect portions. I couldn't keep up. I mean it was like some dude would just walk past me and say 8 grapes for 37 and place a basket of freshly washed grapes in front of me and expect me to scoop out exactly 296 grapes in less than 30 seconds. There was other shit too like placing scoops of PERFECTLY measured rice into trays that were moving on a conveyer belt at the speed of light, and about 30 minutes into that the rice scooper felt like it weighed 500 lbs.....and there were motherfuckers doing that shit for like 12 hours straight. I never looked at a tv dinner the same way after that job.

I think the sheer number of desserts that require raw egg is really a testament to how safe they are to eat. Studies show only 1 in 30,000 eggs even has a salmonella problem. Healthy chickens with lots of sun exposure aren’t going have much salmonella to pass on to their eggs.

Just know that a healthy body is equipped to fight bacteria on its own. No matter what we eat, whether it’s raw or cooked, we encounter bad bacteria all the time (like on vegetables, for instance). The trick to avoiding salmonella in eggs is buying them fresh and using them in the right amount of time.

Raw eggs, as opposed to cooked, are packed with healthy protein and a variety of vitamins, minerals, and loads of vitamins like A, D, B2, B6, B9, B12, iron, and zinc. Not to mention omega 3 and 6 fatty acids, making them a great food in a healthy diet. When eggs are used raw they retain all of this natural goodness. When cooked, some of the omegas and vitamins are retained, but at least 1/4 are lost in the cooking process.

it's not the exception. every single sherry cask influenced whisky I've had have been easily drinkable at the worst. bourbon barrels require more finesse because first fill and virgin oak can easily overpower the malt character and 4th+ refill gives hardly any flavor inside of a decade.

>>18877773
I came up with the idea for Peat Monster, nice to see it mentioned here. The first batch was a 50/50 blend of Caol Ila and Clynelish (or maybe Ardmore, it was a long time ago lol), both about 10 or 15 years old, aged in ex-bourbon, and bottled at cask strength. It was just called Monster. John Glaser, the founder, didn’t want to make it at first because he didn’t personally enjoy peaty whisky. It turned out to be the blend that put him on the map, so he decided to make it regular production item as Peat Monster, with some water added to lower the proof.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
An egg dumplings recipe that my mother got from her grandmother which originated from either Germany or Russia. Can't remember where exactly. Simply take a couple eggs, a couple tablespoons of milk and cup or 2 of flour, beat the eggs and milk together, add flour and beat until thick, scoop out some portions and throw them into boiling water pot and cook for 15-30 minutes. When done cooking scoop out dumplings with spoon with a strainer to remove water and put in bowl applying butter and pepper to your liking.

Been thinking about changing the recipe up abit and adding more too it but I think it's pretty peak poor people food as is.

Cereal, instant ramen, homemade pizzas using the cheapest pizza dough mix, jarred sauce, and store brand cheese available, canned ravioli, spaghetti-os, sandwiches, everything the cheapest possible off-brand from the discount grocery store that only sold whatever cheap shit they could get that week.

I was fully aware how shit our situation was from a pretty young age, decided when I moved out I wasn't going to do that shit anymore and started teaching myself to cook immediately.

Oh yeah, you fucking knew. When you are relying on school free lunch/breakfast to get you by, you sure as fuck knew you were poor. Hotdogs, beans, cheap ground meat. Anything on sale. Margarine. Later on it got replaced with eating out because we came into money.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Grew up almost hillbilly poor but never realized it. My mom had a nice but small house. We ate a lot of beans and pasta and eggs from our coop. We also grew a lot of zucchini, tomatoes and potatoes and had fruit trees. She canned a lot but i thought that was just how everyone ate so I didn't really know any better. I look back on it all fondly

Two embarrassing stories, our school had some kind of park outing. They ordered those giant 9 foot subway sandwiches for the class. Everyone was supposed to chip in a couple of dollars but my brother and I had nothing so we had to eat our pb&j sandwiches while all the other kids feasted.
Second one I was spending the day at a friends house. They decide to go out to dinner to some pizza place. Told me it was a family thing and I could come along but couldn't eat with them I had to buy my own food.
Now that I think about it that family were kind of assholes. That wasn't the first time they fucked with me. They knew we were dirt poor and they were rich. Probably why they never let me hang out with their kid again after that.
Being a poor kid living in a relatively well off neighborhood was hell. Everyone I knew at school/church was always going on ski trips and shit and we never got to go along with anything.

>>18876648
i wasn't particularly poor myself but my parents both grew up either very poor or in a family massive enough to have to worry about food costs between so many kids. as a result they continued a habit as adults of buying the absolute lowest priced value foods to the cent they could find even though they never needed to by the time me or my brother were old enough to care. they were actually really resourceful when it came to cooking so the food was good but occasionally i got some unfortunate stuff such as

>meat frozen so long it tasted like nothing by the time we did eat it
>the occasional expired dollar store food, never understood this because there was a legitimate grocery store literally next door with comparable prices
>mom would always yell at me for taking a pack of 2 poptarts instead of just 1 to school at age 13, where my morning was basically leaving the house at 5am for a long ass bus trip and no school lunch until noon
>incredibly low amounts of salt or spices ever used, didn't grasp this until it clicked why homemade plain chicken tasted nothing like restaurant chicken
>yelling over who opened a cereal
>yelling over who finished a pack of anything, but also yelling over who left a small amount of a pack of anything
>insistence that the same coffee grounds be reused, i thought coffee was just shit water until adulthood because this was obviously not good
>the occasional bizarre leftovers creation that was hit or miss, later learned that this was usually a result of my dad being bored. he still does this to this day and it's usually something pretty cool nowadays but he holds himself to such a high standard and expectations for what amounts to "mix of whatever is in the fridge"

however there was some stuff i really did like that i still eat now that im on my own, like cheap frozen fish and pierogis.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not poor but I'm a social worker.
I've seen three "types" of home, in the first three family has some money but is dysfunctional, all the food is junk food, the freezer is full of pizza, the fridge is full of soft drink. This isn't nearly as expensive as you might imagine because of how calorie dense these foods acrually are. Kids skip meals, throw tantrums when food runs out, binge eat, get fat.

In the second type of home there's no money but at least one tired and stressed family member cooks. Often it's monotonous and totally unseasoned, boiled frozen vegetables, pasta, boiled eggs. Meat offcuts or frozen hotdogs in a pan, boiled potatoes. There's a variant for every ethnicity, but this is actually far better nutrition wise.

Third household is begging and stealing, everyone hoards and hides food, the only things in the fridge are moldy or fouled.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18881748
Buy in bulk, even cheaper brands are fine even if they don't taste as much. They also last very long so you're not wasting any of it.
The money I save by buying slightly less quality meat for a month can be used to buy said oils and spices that will last several months so when you got that down upgrade meat as budget allows. We're not talking about a full cabinet of 20 spices either, just the most basic ones. I'm assuming salt and pepper are not included so rosemary, thyme, oregano, chili and one or two more after preference. Obviously you can't expect getting fresh stuff constantly unless planting it yourself.

I just know I'd prefer more basic meals with a larger choice of spices and oils to make variations than simply upgrading the meat quality slightly and not having said stuff. Worst case you can get piece by piece as budget allows since it, again, lasts very long (oils and spices).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18876648
Grew up fairly poor, 2 children single mom on teacher salary. I don't think there was really any consistent thread to what we ate. Mom cooked the vast majority of meals, either from scratch or instant, and we didn't eat much meat. The stuff she'd make from scratch was mostly soups and stews, and we ate a lot of rice and vegetables. We still could eat at mcdonalds or get pizza sometimes, but it was uncommon enough that it felt like a treat when we did. If there was anything that was missing it's snacks. She'd never buy soda, juice, cookies, or chips with the groceries. The only time we'd get a dessert after a meal is if we went to subway she'd get a single cookie to split between the three of us. If I went to a friend's house and they had snacks and sodas it seemed like the height of luxury. All in all I think she did a really good job since I only really realized how poor we were looking back on it. Even though she wasn't the greatest cook, food anxiety was never an issue for us and we developed fairly healthy eating habits.

>>18876648
We grew up rich but had to eat poor. We even had to help out with the cooking. We never got fast food, popcorn, cola, chips, sandwiches from Subway, Starbucks coffee or ketchup from a bottle (exceptions were Christmas, Easter, and our anniversaries in July and August). We had to help plant, reap, peel and pickle onions, leek, cornichons, make pig stews, sausages and candy with paws, ears, tails and blood. We had to learn which fish and shellfish are in season and how to peel, fillet and batter them.

To this day I spend 1/10th per month on food of what poor people spend (source: /ck/). Yet I eat like ancient European nobility (source: nunya).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mum did her best raising 5 kids by herself, and we had food on the table which is more than a lot can say so I'd never complain about it especially now. She put herself through medical school to become a nurse to provide for us, she was hard working and I appreciate everything she did.

Pajeet Canadian. My family was poor but we ate three full meals a day plus some goyslop. Rarely ever ordered takeout, maybe 2 slices of pizza or 3 donuts once every few weeks that we would share between the 6 of us.

Dinner was a fresh beef/chicken curry and fresh white rice. When we got really broke, no meat curry, it was tuna mixed into Dahl (lentil soup). Often with lettuce and cucumbers. And apple juice (a 2L can was a $1).

Lunch the next day was leftover dinner but the curry would be reheated with a cup of water mixed in so it was wateryyyy. The curry was made thin originally too. So we got like two ounces of meat per meal max.

Lunch packed for school was a strawberry jam sandwich.

Thank you very much kind anons, and please enjoy the chart I made! It took me over 9000 hours in MS paint.

>>18889571
I have the NS-LHC05XT, which is the Indian model. The Zojirushi in your picture is the NS-LGCO5XB which is the American model. The difference is that one has a jasmine rice button and the other has a steel cut oats button.

You list 3-cup size as a con, but actually it's a pro. Unless you have a family you'll never use all 3 cups. Keep in mind that it's talking about dry cups -- that's 1900 calories of rice. You're really gonna eat more than that in one sitting?

If you're not gonna eat more than that in one sitting, the smaller cup size is actually better than the bigger cup size. 1 cup of rice cooks better in the 3-cup pot than in the 5-cup pot. That's because less of it is "on the bottom" and more of it is "in the middle." It also stays more steamed since it's more cozy. I bought that one specifically because it's the smallest pot cooker I could find and it's a phenomenal device.

>>18892395
All rice (white, brown, wild) short grain, medium grain, long grain) absorbs the same amount of water proportionately. The only difference in cooking is time, because brown and wild rice need longer cooking time than white rice. This longer cooking time means more evaporation occurs, which is why it needs more water at the start.

So rice cookers still aren’t needed if you just have knowledge and measure the water properly.

you need to get the oil properly hot. almost to the smoke point. either do a water drop test before adding it or just heat it until you get the slightest bit of smoke. make sure you swirl it so it covers the cooking surface properly. it's like a one use seasoning.
meats usually stick like a mf, but they release fairly easily when they're fully seared so just be patient.
if something sticks you can add a small amount of water right by it and it should come off.

Somalis eat a banana with literally every dish. It's weird, but primitive countries generally don't have a rigid distinction between sweet and savoury dishes the way they do. In some regions of Uganda, boiled bananas are their staple carb, they eat dishes such as boiled bananas with beans.

Another weird thing done with spaghetti in Africa is the Ethiopian way of eating it. They eat spaghetti in tomato sauce but the whole thing is served on an injera (very thin pancake made of teff wheat, with a sour taste because the dough is left to ferment for a few days). See pic related for an example.

Yucatecan is my favorite Mexican regional cuisine. It's alot of citrus, habanero, interesting colors, balancing between bright citrus and spicy with earthy annatto and deep black charred produce, seafood, and the infamous cocinita pibil. Some yucatecan deep cuts are sikil pak (it's like a roasted habanero pumpkin seed salsa with the consistency of hummus), xni pec (pink fruity habanero salsa), Recado negro (black habanero salsa made out of burned chiles and tortillas), panuchos/salbutes (puffy tostada/tacos stuffed with beans), and huaraches (Mexican flat breads)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18889540
Darker roasts will offgas very quickly, but the exposed surface oils will oxidize and go rancid just as quickly. Thats the skunky stale smell you get from grocery store bags. Spoiled plant fat doesn't taste good, drink those within a month off roasting. Anything lighter than that will be fine a good while longer if you're not constantly getting in the bag exposing it to fresh oxygen. Thats where shit like airscape containers(anything sealed with a one way valve really) come in handy. You're not letting fresh oxygen react with the roasted plant fats inside your beans, while letting them vent carbon dioxide. co2 doesn't taste good. Thats why you stir crema on espresso into the shot. Its a sour bitter layer of trapped gasses preventing you from getting to the actual flavors you're trying to extract. Resting will depend on the roast and density of the bean. There's no harm in testing how they taste once a week, just avoid constant exposure to fresh oxygen. Also why people like the meme single dosing tubes.
https://www.wired.com/2009/10/your-tongue-the-carbon-dioxide-sensor/

>>18889137
Buy what you can drink within 2-4 weeks. By the time roasted coffee gets to you it has rested enough. Coffee is rested for 1-3 days after roasting for the flavors to develop. Do not confuse this with the spergy weeks-long CO2 off-gassing espresso dorks do. They do this so that they can more precisely dial in their shots at the expense of losing flavor. I repeat: they are losing flavor as a trade off for replicability of espresso shot extraction. The volatile aromatic compounds that give good, fresh coffee its taste are lost over time. It is very noticeable after about 2-4 weeks.

Here's my tip for this situation, which I have been in (and gotten laid in).
Pre-make a chocolate dessert in tumblers/wine glasses at home. I went with layered mascarpone, chocolate mousse and ganache with crushed amaretti biscuits. I happened to have some nice heavy Old Fashioned glasses to use but anything approx that size is fine. Practice if you need to at home, and transport them in a cooler bag with some freezer blocks or ice.
Cook whatever you like at her home. Something simple like pasta with any one-pot sauce, aglio e olio and mushrooms, whatever. Presentation is not THAT important and in fact a home-cooked charm is more useful. If you feel flush with cash pick a more ritzy ingredient or two to highlight (steaks can work, or fancy cheeses, or the like). The dessert will be buying you the majority of the brownie points and you know it's good before you walk in the door. Pressure is off. Use the opportunity to get your James Bond on and talk to her while you work.

from an autist with experience: make a galette. it's impossible for them to be ugly and there're a lot of options for fillings.
i doubt she'll care if you buy store-bought pie crust, but you can always make that ahead.
dust crust with parmesan, pesto, or dijon (or a combination of these)
prep filling (cook onion/garlic and parboil veggies. and cheese, herbs, and seasonings) then arrange on center of crust crust. fold over edges, do egg wash, then bake at 400 Fahrenheit for 30-40 minutes
BONUS: if you buy storebought crust, use the second crust in the package for a fruit galette for dessert. bake it at the same time as the savory one
i can give flavor ideas if you want, too. i recommend getting it simple

1/2 of a package mini smoked sausages
about a quarter to 3rd of a bag of frozen mixed vegetables
1/4 cup milk
1/4 cup butter
salt

boil water. salt up the water, the normal amount for making pasta. when it comes to a boil throw in the frozen veggies. cut the little smokies in half. when the water returns to boiling (the frozen veggies will cool it a bit) throw in the macaroni from the mac and cheese and the sausages. cook the amount of time it says on the box. then drain everything, take pot off heat, after draining toss back in the pot and mix in the milk, cheese sauce powder, and butter. stir vigorously and then let sit 5 minutes. serve.

>>18890407
I'm going to give you honest criticism, OP...

The mushroom sauce doesn't look too bad. It does look like it needed to be further thickened/emulsified. I would not have used corn starch as a thickener for that sauce, since it requires such a high temperature.

The chicken does not actually look undercooked to me, despite the pinkness. I do hope that you checked the temperature, though. My biggest issue here is that you didn't properly roast the chicken. Roasting is a method that requires dry, indirect heat, ideally you would suspend the chicken as much as possible. It's common in commercial kitchens, when roasting in large ovens, to either hang the meat by hooks or place it on a rotisserie device. That vessel is not ideal for roasting, and you mentioned you placed a lid on it, which means during some part of the cooking process you were actually braising which is pretty much the complete opposite of roasting. You ended up with the worst of both methods; a chicken that did not get roasty, crispy, and browned on the outside, nor did it break down the connective tissues and become soft and flavorful inside as it would if you had been braising.

And finally, your pasta is undercooked. "Al dente" does not mean uncooked, it basically just means "not mushy".

Don't be discouraged, anon. I recommend you try this dish again.

Ingredients (mostly from left to right)
>Masoor Dal
>Ghee
>Yellow Onion
>Lime
>Salt
>Corriander (fresh)
>Serrano chilis
>Canned tomatoes
>dried red chilis
>ginger garlic paste
>garam masala
>cumin seed (whole)
Kasmiri chili powder
>corriander (ground seed)
>Hing AKA Asafoetida
Not pictured:
>Dried kasuri methi
>turmeric powder
>probably something else I'll remember later


A few notes:
Red onions are more traditional for most Indian cooking. I need to use up my yellow onions though.
Serrano chilis are a Mexican chili but they work just fine in Indian food. You can find more traditional green chilis at your local Indian grocery store. Some traditionalists will be appalled at the idea of using something like jalapeños, but they're just fine.

posts.com: This is what the masoor dal looks like up close.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I always give my dal a quick soak for a minute or two and then rinse it to get it cleaned off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
While the dal is soaking, I prepare my spice blend. I like to prepare my spice blend ahead of time because it makes it less likely I'll forget some spices. Normally, you'd add garam masala at the end because it's already toasted and doesn't need more cooking. This garam masala I bought was not toasted ahead of time so I'm mixing it in with the other spies.

I'll post the full recipe including the spice blend at the end of this thread.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
After rinsing the dal off, I put it on the stove with 3 cups of water for a 3 cups water to 1 cup dal ratio. I bring to a boil and then reduce to a simmer.

While the dal cooks on a pot on the stove, I use the time to prep my ingredients. I'm dicing the onion, chopping the chili, and redicing the tomatoes. The tomato can says diced, but it's a scam because they're big huge chunks. You gotta dice them extra. I prefer to just buy the whole canned tomatoes and do all the cutting myself rather than these partially diced ones.

Unless tomatoes are in season, I always use canned. Out of season grocery store tomatoes absolutely suck and are completely inferior to canned 'matoes. Even in season grocery store tomatoes are usually questionable. Buy them at a farmers' market or grow your own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Next, I heat up my pan and dump some ghee in it. If you think that's a lot of fat, you should see how much Indian restaurants in America and the UK use.

You want to get your onions to sort of a golden color. They should be soft and translucent, but you don't want to fully caramelize them. Unfortunately, I didn't take a good picture to show you guys the level I got them to.

Next I added a some garlic ginger paste. I should really just make my own garlic ginger paste, but I'm lazy. Unless you cook a lot of Indian food, do not buy a big ass jar of ginger garlic paste.

Keep cooking until the "raw" smell of ginger garlic paste goes away. This usually takes a minute or two.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18894241
You're not making a puree so you still want to still be able to see individual lentils even though they're quite soft. You should be able to take one between thumb and forefinger, give them a rub together, and turn the lentil into mush. If the lentil still has some shape when you do this, simmer longer. Cooking time can vary a lot depending on the type of dal and how old it is. I think these took about 45 minutes.

If you've got too much water left when they're done, take a fine mesh strainer and pour liquid through it. The liquid will go through the mesh and the dal will remain in the strainer. I err on the side of having too much water rather than not enough after a disaster where I cooked off all the water a few years ago. As long as you're paying attention, you can just add more water if it runs low.

Nice work OP, im Paki myself and enjoy cutting the onions long wise (crescent moon shape) this allows the onions to be thinner and melt easier in the final dish. Up to preference though same as the oil, i like making mine rather lean (less surface area on the onions helps with that) . Also add your chilis at the boiling phase to prevent burning, and add a few extra whole ones if you like it really spicy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Now that the spices are all mixed in with the onions, dump your tomatoes in and start mixing. The acid in the tomatoes will sort of freeze the cooking of the onions so they won't turn into a blackened mess.

You want to cook the tomatoes until they're nice and mushy. You should be able to see the oil separating from the 'matoes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some details on the spices I added before the tomatoes:

Coriander powder: it's made from ground coriander seeds. I suck at describing spices, but you probably already know what this one tastes like.
Kashmiri chili powder: this is a pretty mild chili powder made from Kashmiri chilis. It has a strong red color. Flavorwise, it's kind of like paprika with a very mild amount of heat. You could also use a hotter chili powder (usually just sold as chili powder at your local Indian grocery store). Do not use American style chili powder. It's got a bunch of stuff besides ground chilis in it and does not have the sort of flavor profile you want. Save it for things like tex-mex.
Turmeric: turmeric is fun because it's extremely yellow and can turn all sorts of things like your stove, clothes, and hands yellow if you get it everywhere. It has an earthy flavor.
Hing AKA Asafoetida: It has an allium (that's the plant family things like onions and garlic are from) sort of flavor and a little goes a long way.
Salt: I err on the side of caution and just use a little salt in the initial spice blend. It's easy to add more salt, it's really hard to fix a dish that's too salty. Some people fear salt, but unless you've got salt sensitive blood pressure, it's not something you need to worry about. If your Indian cooking tastes bland, odds are the problem is that you didn't use enough salt rather than not using enough spices. Salt brings out the flavors of spices, vegetables, lentils, beans etc.
Garam masala: Garam means warm, masala means spice. Garam masala can vary a lot and every brand will use different spices and in different amounts. It's a spice mix of ingredients like cumin, mace, cinnamon, cloves, fennel, star anise. Every mix will be made differently. Most of the time, it's made from spices that have already been toasted in which case you should add it at the end of cooking. Mine seems to be made from spices that weren't toasted before they were ground so I added it earlier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
RECIPE:
Makes at least 4 servings.

For the lentils:
1 cup masoor dal (red lentils)
3 cups water (this is what I used for stovetop. Pressure cookers are common in Indian cooking, but since I don’t have one at the moment, please look up how much water to use if using one. I don’t want to give out a wrong number

For the recipe (ingredients in order of adding to to pan)

3-4 tablespoons ghee (use a different oil to make it vegan)
2 tsp cumin seeds
1 or 2 dried red chilis, broken in half. Some people would remove the seeds. I don’t.
1 medium onion, diced (I got a bit over a cup of onion out of mine). Red onion is recommended but
1 green chili, diced or slit. Dice it for more heat, slit it for less. An Indian green chili like jwala or a Serrano chili will give you a more authentic flavor, but feel free to use something jalapeño if that’s what you have or like.
1 tablespoon ginger garlic paste (alternatively, just mince an equivalent amount of fresh ginger and garlic and use that.)
1/2 tsp coriander powder
1 big pinch of hing (asafetida)
3/4 tsp garam masala
1 tsp turmeric powder
1 tsp Kashmiri chili powder. Use a chili powder just sold as “chili powder” at your Indian grocery store for more heat. Do not use American chili powder which has a flavor profile better suited for tex-mex. If I were using a hotter Indian “chili powder” I’d use less than 1 tsp. Kashmiri chili powder will always be labeled “Kashmiri Chili Powder” rather than just “Chili Powder”
Salt (small amount, you will add more at the end.)
1 can worth of tomatoes, diced
1-2 tsp of dried kasuri methi (fenugreek)
1 or 2 tsp of lime juice (could also use lemon or amchur powder)
2-3 tablespoons of chopped coriander leaves

Part 1/?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
To make your dal (lentils):
Soak your dal for a minute or two, drain, and rinse.
Mix your water and the masoor dal. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer. Check every once-in-awhile to see how they’re cooking. Mine took about 45 minutes.
You still want to still be able to see individual lentils even though they're quite soft. You should be able to take one between thumb and forefinger, give them a rub together, and turn the lentil into mush. If the lentil still has some shape when you do this, simmer longer.
Once your dal is the right level of doneness, mash some of them your spoon or a mashing utensil. You don’t want to mash all of them. Remove from heat.

The rest of the dish
Heat ghee on low, add your whole cumin seeds and red chili. Make the cumin seeds crackle but do not overcook. If they’re burned, start over.
Add onions and green chili, turn your heat up to medium, and cook until the onions are a nice golden color.
Add your ginger garlic paste and cook until the raw smell goes away.
Add your spices (turmeric, coriander powder, garam masala*, Kashmiri chili powder, hing, a little salt) and mix until it’s nicely blended.
Add your tomatoes, cook and stir until the tomatoes are mushy and the oil is separating from the tomatoes.
Pour the dal in, reduce to low, and simmer for a few minutes. Add more water if needed and taste for salt at this point. You will likely need to add more salt. If there’s not much flavor, the problem is probably lack of salt. Salt brings out flavors and lets them shine.
Crush the kasuri methi between your palms by rubbing them together and let it fall into the pan. It helps to say voilà (wah-lah in /ck/ speak) once the last bit of kasuri methi falls in.
Add lime juice and chopped coriander
Mix everything around one final time.
Serve with roti or basmati rice.

*in most cases you would add garam masala at the end. I added it here because mine was not previously toasted.

Imagine this scenario: you're a soldier in Vietnam, sweeping through a patch of jungle with your unit. You awaken some time later. It could be minutes, hours, days, even a week. You survived. You're the last living man on a battlefield strewn with corpses, friend and foe alike, of which those with the least bloated and maggot-infested have long since been scavenged by man and jungle beast alike. Imagine the smell, that rotting putrid meat smell, the dried blood rotten fruit stench permeating all around the wet ripe jungle mud and coating your nose and skin and eyes and tongue with its 100-degree tropical humidity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18884341
ok, first I chuckled, but then I realized you're not trolling, so lets break it down, shall we?
>fry some onions and garlic in butter
first of all, not some onions, but you caramelize onions.
second, not some garlic, but garlic and ginger, and you do these separetely, only for around 30 seconds or so, otherwise you will burn them.
And no, not butter, but ghee. If you don't have ghee, use regular oil, don't use butter, lol.
>add curry powder and let it combine and cook for a bit
wait, actually good advice? well, almost. for 500g of meat I recommend 2 tablespoons of good quality curry powder, but actually I recommend adding around 200ml of passata, cooking it for a couple of minutes, and then adding spices, which then you cook a bit more to get out their true flavours.
>add milk
for krishna's sake, never, absolutely, n e v e r add milk.
add chicken, then when no longer pink, dilute everything with a bit of water
>Then finish cooking seared chicken in it (thighs work great)
total gibberish, I'm not even bother deciphering it, it does says chicken though, so no, that's the wrong time to put the chicken in.
thighs do work great though. 5 points for slytherin (that's where I imagine you would be after writing such low quality recipe)
>Let the chicken simmer in there for 30 minutes
wtf, I love dry mushy chicken? just kidding, give it 20 minutes top.
>The curry powder thickens the sauce by itself so you don't have to do anything else to it.
o boy, there we go. curry powder will not thicken the sauce whatsoever. not even a bit, nope, runny, watery, curry on your way sir!
remember that mythical passata we added earlier? yep, that's your main thickener.
>Pile it on rice and w'Allah
first of all, you forgot to add a little bit of heavy cream, just a tad to mellow the spices.
and second of all, no, don't pile it on rice, pour it into a bowl and add a bit at the time on your rice platter, next to the rice. you want easy access to plain rice to cleanse the palette.

The sauce that makes up the curry is usually a very thick pureed vegetable stock made from onions, garlic, carrots, tomato and bell peppers that spices are then added to. The meat or veg of the dish is usually fried in ghee with a garlic & ginger puree, has about a tablespoon of whatever spice mixture is required for the dish and then 1/4 cup of condensed tomato paste and a couple of ladles of that vegetable stock are added in until they get the right consistency/colour. There's a lot more veg in an Indian curry than almost any other kind of takeaway.

>>18892572
You can't really rinse toxins out of meat, because water alone simply can't clean things.

A lot of people believe that washing chicken disinfects it. It really doesn't. What it does however is removes, in the case of unchlorinated chickens, a lot of impurities that were left during the slaughtering process. The slime also has a gamey taste to it, so adding water helps to dilute that.

More often than not, traiditional washing in most countries is done by adding some acids, such as lemon or vinegar, that react with the chemical compounds associated with stronger smells. They don't hose the chicken, they either put it in a brining solution (not too long so that it actually brines, just a quick bath), or they rub it with some lemon and salt and then wash it off to remove the lemon and salt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18893857
The spice level on jalapenos varies a lot
Sometimes they're not spicy, just barely more than a bell pepper
Sometimes they're spicy enough to give you burns if you get them on your skin
Depends on when and where they were grown, and what other peppers are grown nearby
Jalapenos that are fat and round are less spicy
The skinny, pointy ones are more spicy, especially if they are triangular at the stem

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18878544
>Any recommendations from /ck/?
make your own
a bulk pack of dried ramen and a can of vegeta only takes 5 minutes + however long it takes to get the water boiling (and costs far less per serve than packets of instant), and you can improve it from there by making stock yourself, using fresh meat or vegetables, a splash of soy sauce or hoisin or some other sauce, aroma oils etc.
It's also less wasteful since you aren't throwing away massive amounts of plastic wrapping, foil sauce packets.
Once you start making your own you'll quickly realise how oily and artificial the instant ramens are.

I remember I went to visit China, specifically Bejing, when I was in grade school with my mom. She was a teacher and took some students over on exchange for a month. Would have been mid to late 90s.

The best thing I ever ate over there was a sweet potato we bought off a street vendor like this, he had a massive barrel with coals in the bottom and would roast the potatoes inside.

Crazy how seeing this took me back to that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
whenever i have a mixed drink after the first time i've tried one i probably change the ratios because i don't like more than one and i can make them taste better

bourbon buck: 2 shots of bourbon, whole can of ginger ale, poured over a smashed at the bottom of the cup like half a lemon

gorilla tit+: 1:1:1:1 rum:bourbon:khalua:coconut cream

gin & tonic, been told it's closer to something else but also not the same but i forget the name: 2 shots gin (tanqueray rangpur (it's limey)), can of key lime la croix, poured over a smashed at the bottom of the glass half lime, juice the other half and dump that in

really good coffee: 1 shot meyers dark rum (it's brown sugary), enough whole milk to bring the rum and milk up to 3/4 of the mug, fill the mug the rest of the way with cold brew concentrate (130g dark roast grounds mixed & submerged in a 16.9 oz bottle of waters worth of water for 12 hours before strained)

(not my recipe and i forget if this is the real name but i'm pretty sure it is) deconstructed screwdriver: dip orange slice in sugar, take a shot of vodka and bite sugar coated orange slice

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I love the classic Americano

1 1/2 ounces Campari
1 1/2 ounces sweet vermouth
Soda water, chilled, to top
Garnish: orange twist

Pros:
Delicious, not too sweet but flavorful, can make it strong or easy to drink, has a classic feel, isn't girly

Cons
Campari and sweet/red vermouth aren't exactly common home bar liquors, although they shouldn't be too hard to obtain
Some bartenders don't know it or don't remember since it's not a common order so you may have to remind them of the recipe, so not something you want to order when it's super busy somewhere

I like making Mint Juleps, because they are easy as fuck to make, but also makes it feel like you're still 'making a cocktail, instead of just pouring two liquors into a cup with a mixer.
>muddle some mint leaves and sugar in a 'muddleable' glass gently, as you just want to release the oils and shit in the leaves
>add crushed ice (and it can't be cubed, trust me)
>pour over 2-3 shots of your favorite bourbon
>stir

I personally will also add lime zest to the muddle, and a little lime juice to top.

>>18893824
A few other things:

If you're expecting chuck steak, you're going to be disappointed by chicken. Chicken, fish, beef, etc. are all good and have their places in recipes, but they're not quite comparable. If you're expecting one to be like another, you're going to be disappointed.

Under salting can often be a cause lack of flavor. Salt really brings out the flavors of seasonings and meats. If you're just putting a salt-free spice rub or something on chicken, or just using a tiny amount of salt, you're not going to bring out the flavors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18889314
You never use dried herbs for anything that won't rehydrate them like stock or soup or a sauce, not stuff that stays relatively dry. It won't seep out any flavor otherwise as the oils won't have the time to leave the herbs and get into the food.

posts.com:
>>18892209
What do you think about my method for cooking apple pie?

I precook the apples in a covered fry pan with butter until all the apples have softened and collapsed. This has several benefits:

- Allows the cut apples to cook before they've had a chance to oxidize and turn brown from sitting out for too long, which is a problem with cooking pie the traditional way where the fruit filling isn't cooked until it goes in the oven with the pie. Some recipes try to solve this problem by instructing you to cover the peeled/sliced apples with lemon juice, but this isn't that effective as just cooking them straight away before they've had a chance to turn brown.
- When apples cook, they soften, collapse, and release a lot of excess water which can make the pie soggy. By cooking them in the pan, you can control this variable and reduce that excess liquid into a syrup and intensify the apple flavor and its natural sweetness. Many recipes try to mitigate this problem by instructing you to add flour or starch to the pie filling, or to let the sliced apples sit in sugar to drain off some excess liquid. but once again if you let the apples sit out for too long they'll turn brown. And what do you do with that excess liquid? you can drain it off which is wasteful, or reduce that to a glaze or syrup, which is already accomplished in my method anyway, and no need for any additional starch in the filling.
- by cooking the pie filling in a pan, it's your opportunity to achieve nice caramelization of the various ingredients like the butter, the apples, and the sugar if you desire, which cannot happen in the oven if the pie is covered in a crust. Even if the top of the pie is exposed, you may only get browning on that surface but not throughout the pie filling.

>>18892324
I know the firmer varieties like granny smith are used in apple pie due to the fact that they hold their shape better after cooking, and their higher sourness over the delicious varieties is said to balance out the sweetness of the pie better, but i still go for the delicious varieties for a few reasons. First reason is i dont mind if the apple pie filling ends up soft and mushy. In fact i kind of like that. It can contrast with the crusty pie crust. But even so, the apples never get as mushy as applesauce unless if you actually mashed them like potatoes which I don’t do. I’m still left with satisfying pieces of apple in the finished pie. Second reason is the natural sweetness of the apples can be balanced out by adding acid if desired. Acid from any citrus fruit is a good way to go, and some recipes i’ve seen even use balsamic vinegar. I’m not a big fan of that much sourness so i leave the apples as is.

So the apples i use are simply my favorite apples. Honeycrisp, fuji, and red delicious

1. Brown the ground beef in a pan, maybe season it with some stuff. Salt, pepper, garlic, onions... peppers?
2. Make a grilled cheese sandwich, use low heat and leave the top half of the bread off.
3. When cheese melts, take some of cooked ground beef mixture and press it evenly into the melted cheese.
4. Place 2nd sliced of bread on (and more cheese?) and flip, fry until finished.
5. Serve cut in half with w/e condiments you want for dipping.

Not a burger or a patty melt, would call it a... loose meat grilled cheese?

>australian answer
I grew up on an olive farm, so I grab another 2L cask from family whenever I run low

On the rare occasion I need to buy some I'll get cobrams estate or red island as good quality at their price point.

The easymode rules:
>but actual olive oil (looking at you america)
>buy as local as reasonable, anything imported will usually be older
>buy as close to the harvest/crushing date as possible. The 'best before' date is fine to compare across brands.
Age is key for flavour. If you want some sharp grassy flavours, get an early press as young as possible. If all you want is cooking oil, 2 years old is fine.

I've been eating nothing but microwave burritos, peanut butter sandwhiches, instant ramen, mandarines and I feel like shit (not fat BMI is 18).

birds are everywhere and have a surprising amount of meat

>>18894757
You can cook quite a lot in a microwave. It won't be great, but it'll be healthy. Stab a potato with a fork a few times then microwave for 10 mins to make a baked potato. If you have a glass container with a lid you can boil pasta or rice in it. To both of these you can add store sauces, frozen or fresh veg, cheese, and whatever else you want. Meat is the tricky part, you either have to live with dry chicken breasts/mince or stick with deli meats.

japan (and to some degree china, and to much less of a degree korea and vietnam and thailand) get a gold star sticker almost on the level of italy just for ramen (lamian).

but. japan perfected an east hemisphere answer to the west's pasta.

japanese pasta (ramen. soba. most of their shit. but really ramen, with the broths, my god the broths!) is the brother to italian pasta. one with alkaline, the other with eggs. one chewy and chimerical, the other severe but succulent, tender. it's a great example of a couplet across the world, one is the gauzy delicate rice field, the other a hardy but diaphanous wheat field.

The American south historically grew most of the world's cotton. Cotton heavily depletes the nitrogen in soil and people didn't have access to modern fertilizers, so a common method of replenishing was to plant nitrogen fixers like peanuts. This led to an absolute glut of peanuts that producers couldn't get rid of in raw form and the popularization of peanut butter.
